Classifications: Test: Who can Go Deepest in Earth?
Variation Example: The birds agree that whichever of them can go deepest in the earth will be their king. The wren goes down into a mousehole. The other birds try to starve him out. The owl is supposed to guard the exit of the hole, but the wren escapes nevertheless.

Classifications: War between Birds (Insects) & Quadrupeds
Variation Example: A bear (wolf, lion) insults the children of a wren (insults an insect). The wren declares war, & the flying animals fight against the quadrupeds. The fox leads the quadrupeds & lifts his tail to signal that they are on the advance. Gnats bite the fox under the tail, so he lowers it. The quadrupeds think they have lost & retreat. The flying animals win.

Classifications: Bat in the War Between Birds & Quadrupeds
Variation Example: Because of its ambiguous form the bat joins first one side & then the other, but it always takes the side of the winner. The animals notice this when they make peace. Consequently, the bat is despised by all animals.

Classifications: Quarrel between Mouse & Sparrow
Variation Example: A mouse & a sparrow want to share the food they have stored for the winter (try to divide a single remaining grain). Their quarrel turns into a war between birds & quadrupeds in which the eagle is injured.

Classifications: The Bird & the Jackal
Variation Example: A jackal (fox) orders a bird (often a lark) to obtain food. The bird flies near men carrying baskets of food. The men drop the baskets to pursue the bird & the jackal eats the food. The jackal orders the bird to make him laugh. The bird lands on the heads of two men so that they fight with one another. The jackal orders the bird to make him cry. The bird leads men or dogs to the jackals’s hiding place. The jackal orders the bird to save his life. The bird lures the jackal to a crocodile, then strikes the crocodile so that the jackal is able to escape.

Classifications: Bird Wedding
Variation Example: Misc. type. Birds (turtle & peacock, frog & mouse, owl & hoopoo, lark & nightingale, etc.) or insects (beetle, grasshopper, ant, etc.) intend to marry. Many guests (birds, insects, other animals) are invited and/or they are assigned to prepare for the wedding. The course of the wedding feast is described (including unpleasant event).

Classifications: Crane Teaches the Fox to Fly
Variation Example: A fox (jackal, wolf, tortoise) asks crane (stork) to teach him to fly. Once high up in the sky, the bird drops the fox. Usually, the fox dies upon hitting the ground, but in some cases he is saved.

Classifications: Tortoise Lets Itself be Carried by Birds
Variation Example: A tortoise is carried up into the air by two birds (herons, geese, swans) who hold onto a stick which the tortoise holds in its mouth. When it speaks, it loses its grip & drops to its death. Or, a bird (eagle) takes the tortoise into the air, drops it so that it smashes, & eats it. Sometimes used to explain why the shell of the tortoise has cracks.

Classifications: The Goose Teaches the Fox to Swim
Variation Example: The goose drowns it. In some (German) variants, the goose teaches the fox to dance & flies away.

Classifications: Geese ask for Respite for Prayer
Variation Example: A fox (wolf) wants to eat geese (ducks, piglets) but they ask him to grant them a last wish: a prayer or a dance. They crackle continuously. Sometimes people come to help them (they are able to escape).

Classifications: The Crow & the Crayfish
Variation Example: A crow catches a crayfish. The crayfish compliments the crow, who opens its beak to reply. The crayfish falls into the water & escapes.

Classifications: A Little Bird Tries to be Bigger
Variation Example: A titmouse (wren) ruffles up her feathers to be as big as a bear but her children laugh at her. In her usual shape (sometimes also gnat, bee) she flies into the bear’s (tiger, wolf) ear & kills him.

Classifications: Animals Fear a Bird's Body Part
Variation Example: A hawk is afraid of a snipe’s bill, but is reassured by the snipe. Other animals fear the rooster (a fox fears a bell) because they believe that it has fire on its head. One animal tells them that it is harmless.

Classifications: The Rearing of the Large-headed & Large-eyed bird
Variation Example: An eagle (hawk) fosters an owl. When he learns how long the owl can live, he kills it.

Classifications: The Race of the Rooster, the Birch-Cock & the Birch-Hen
Variation Example: The animals decide whichever wins a race may live in town (on the farm). The rooster deceives the others & wins.

Classifications: The Heron & the Fish
Variation Example: A heron (crane) tells the fish that their lake is drying up. It promises to transport them one by one to another lake, but eats them instead. A crab sees through the deception, seizes the heron by the throat, & kills it.

Classifications: Animals Eat Each Other
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various tales in which smaller animals are eaten by bigger ones. Sometimes the last one in the food chain (fox, lion, bear) is shot by a hunter or bursts.

Classifications: The Falcoln & the Doves
Variation Example: Doves beg a falcon to help them (they elect him king) but he eats them & their young.

Classifications: Which Bird is Father?
Variation Example: A very small bird goes to God with his adult son, & asks God to guess which of them is the father & which the son. God: “There is a spot on the father’s nose”. The father quickly rubs his nose & God knows the answer.

Classifications: Crow Drops Pebbles into a Water Jug
Variation Example: A thirsty crow drops pebbles into a tall jug of water. The water level rises so that the crow is able to drink from the jug.

Classifications: The Birds Escape by Shamming Death
Variation Example: Birds caught in a fowler’s net (cage) follow the advice of an old bird & pretend to be dead. After the fowler throws them out onto the ground, they fly away.

Classifications: Birds Fly Off with the Net
Variation Example: Birds caught in a fowler’s net fly off with the net. They fly to a mouse (rat) who gnaws the net & sets them free.

Classifications: The Swallow & the Hemp-Seeds
Variation Example: Birds ignore the advice of a swallow (owl, tortoise) to eat hempseeds (mistletoe) as fast as they are sowed. Ridiculed, the swallow builds his nest among the dwellings of men. Later the other birds are caught in nets made from the hemp. Sometimes used to explain why the swallow lives close to humans.

Classifications: The Birds & the Fowler
Variation Example: Birds see the watery eyes of a hunter (from cold) & think he weeps out of pity for them. One clever bird tells them that it is not so.

Classifications: The Nightingale & the Blindworm
Variation Example: Both have one eye. The nightingale (crow, dove, fox, tick) borrows the blindworm’s eye & then refuses to return it. Since then, she has two eyes & the blindworm has none. The latter lives in a tree where the nightingale has her nest & in revenge bores holes in the nightingale’s eggs.

Classifications: Birds Brew Beer
Variation Example: Birds brew beer in a river with one grain or one ear of grain. They rejoice that the beer is excellent.

Classifications: The Jay Borrows the Cuckoo's Skin
Variation Example: But he does not return it.

Classifications: A Bird has New Clothes Made
Variation Example: It flies away without paying.

Classifications: Magpie Teaches the Dove to Build a Nest
Variation Example: A dove (magpie, sparrow) asks a magpie (thrush, swallow, crow) to show her how to build a nest. As soon as the magpie starts, the dove says “I know”, & persists in building her nest as before, so that the eggs nearly drop out. In some variants the dove promises to give her cow to the magpie & then regrets losing the cow. (Imitation of bird sounds.)

Classifications: Misc. Tales with Imitation of Bird Sounds
Variation Example: Some variants explain the sounds made by bittern & hoopoe. Two herdsmen send their cows to the wrong pasture. The hoopoe & the bittern tell them that one pasture is too rich, & another pasture too poor. (Imitation of bird sounds.)

Classifications: The Talking Parrot
Variation Example: A parrot (in early variants a magpie) gives wrong orders or makes inappropriate remarks & is punished by its master (thrown in the mud, loses the feathers on its head or is chased & hides under the stove). There the parrot meets an animal (sow, cat) or bald person & says, “You too must have had a quarrel with your master”.

Classifications: The Dove & the Frog Boast to Each Other
Variation Example: A dove (falcon, crow) claims to have keen sight, & a frog (bee) believes it hears everything. They demonstrate their abilities to each other.

Classifications: The Crow Helps the Deer Escape from the Snare
Variation Example: A deer helps a jackal, but when the deer is caught in a snare the jackal refuses to help him. On the advice of a crow the deer feigns death. When the hunter releases him, he bounds away.

Classifications: The Dove Trades Her Eggs
Variation Example: A magpie (crow, hen) persuades a dove to exchange eggs (in English variants to exchange nests): the dove gets the two eggs of the magpie for her seven. Since then the dove lays only two eggs & mourns the loss of the other eggs. (Imitation of bird sounds.) In some variants a dove & a hen have a race for the eggs. The hen deceives the dove & wins.

Classifications: The Bee Falls into the Water
Variation Example: A dove saves a bee (ant) from drowning. When a hunter wants to shoot the dove, the bee stings the hunter.

Classifications: The Officious Bird & the Monkey
Variation Example: A bird, sitting in its nest during a cold rain, asks a shivering monkey why it doesn’t build a house since it has hands like a man. The enraged monkey destroys the bird’s nest.

Classifications: The Crow's Oath
Variation Example: A crow (another bird) entices a frog (toad) out of his hole & swears not to eat him. The crow breaks his oath.

Classifications: The Crow Marries
Variation Example: A crow marries because her bridegroom told her that he owns all grainfields. As the grain is being harvested in the autumn, the wife calls out, “Iaak, they are stealing the grain”.

Classifications: The Rooster Who Crows about Mistress's Adultery Killed.
Variation Example: The first rooster crows about the adultery committed by the mistress. He is killed. The second rooster crows about the first rooster being killed for telling the truth. He is also slaughtered. The third rooster is discreet & is allowed to live.

Classifications: Crow in Borrowed Feathers
Variation Example: A raven puts on swan (peacock) feathers. Other birds take them from him & leave him disgraced in the cold. Sometimes a crow borrows feathers from other birds for his wed-ding day.
